INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Brazil has the highest burden of Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) in the Americas, with more than
300,000 cases yearly. CHIKV has a relatively low risk of death but imposes a highly disabling
acute arthritis and associated long-term complications. We hypothesize that besides
biomedical factors; CHIKV?s transmission is affected by specific social determinants. To
identify these determinants and their role on CHIKV?s burden in Fortaleza, Ceara, we used
notified data obtained from SINAN (Brazil?s surveillance system) to identify drivers of the
transmission between 2014-2018. We used multilevel modelling with negative binomial and
Poisson links to identify Incidence Rate Ratios (IRRs), including random effects to account for
spatial (neighborhood level) and temporal autocorrelations. Social covariates included
development index (HDI), ethnicity, education, and other neighborhood characteristics
obtained from census data. There were 77,024 confirmed CHIKV cases reported, (649
hospitalized and 158 deaths). The majority of cases were females 47,574 (61.8%), people over 20 years old 77,024 (84.4%), and Non-Whites 58,486 (75.9%), when a third of the population is white. An increase of $100 USD in income was associated to a 28% and 41% reduction on the incidence rate of CHIKV among non-whites and whites, respectively (IRR non-whites =0.72; 95%CI=0.59-0.87, and IRR whites =0.59; 95%CI=0.48-0.72). An increase of 10% of
literacy was associated to increased incidence rate for bot ethnic categories (IRR non-whites =2.29; 95%CI=1.31-4.01, and IRR whites =1.75; 95%CI=1.04-2.95). Spatial random effects identified a concentration (cluster) area in the central region of the city. Temporal effects showed higher transmission from March-June of each year with a peak on May (IRR=13.9;
95%CI=11.4-17.1), comparing to January. The adjusted marginal ethnic disparity rate difference was 8.5 per 10,000 (95%CI=8.3, 8.8), and the marginal incidence rate ratio was 15.2 (95%CI=15.0, 15.4). We

parecerista interno na Chamada Pública nº 09/2015 e nº 10/2015 UECE
EquityEcoHealth : An innovative ecohealth intervention protecting pregnant women, adolescent and the poorest in Colombia and Brazil

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO-TECNICO.FINALIDADE: Programa de Contrôle de vetores e da difusão da Zika

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Evidence has shown that ecohealth community-based intervention can significantly impact Aedes vector densities, with emerging evidence for an impact on arbovirus transmission. In light of the recent Zika epidemic expanding across much of Latin America, there exists even greater urgency to systematically deploy these measures to protect all women of reproductive age, particularly adolescents and their unborn children and the poorest. This intervention research project will start by provide new evidence about 3 currently implemented ecohealth Aedes control interventions in Brazil (Belo Horizonte and Goiânia) and Colombia (Girardot) to improve it and plan/implement 1 new interventions in Fortaleza (Brazil).

The Research is coordinated by Dr. Valéry Ridde of the University of Montréal, Dr. Andrea Caprara, of the State University of Ceará in Fortaleza (Brazil) and Dr. Catalina
Gonzales Uribe , Fundación Santa Fe de Bogotá, Colombia.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
This World Health Organization (WHO) document was adapted as a generic tool for research in the
investigation of the natural history of Zika virus infection in with collaboration with the International Research
Consortium on Dengue Risk Assessment, Management and Surveillance (IDAMS) and the International Severe
Acute Respiratory and Emerging Infection Consortium (ISARIC).
More information on IDAMS can be found on their website: http://www.idams.eu
More information on ISARIC can be found on their website: https://isaric.tghn.org

Minha participação para a produção deste documento foi enquanto membro do IDAMS

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-PROGRAMA-DE-RADIO-OU-TV.TITULO: EMPOWERING COMMUNITIES TO DENGUE CONTROL. AN ECOHEALTH ANALYSIS AND AN INTEGRATED APPROACH IN FORTALEZA, BRAZIL

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bQYu-pG8ofg
http://www.who.int/tdr/news/2014/dengue-research-brazil/en/

O video publicado pela Organização Mundial da Saúde, documenta as atividades e os resultados de um projeto de pesquisa sobre dengue realizado por Professores e alunos de Mestrado e Doutorado do Programa em Saúde Coletiva da UECE. A pesquisa é parte de um projeto mais amplo apoiado pelo TDR da Organização Mundial da Saúde que encontra como parceiros seja as comunidades seja os serviços de saúde para desenvolver e implementar projetos saudáveis e sustentáveis de um ponto de vista ambiental, para reduzir a transmissão de dengue e da doença de Chagas. O trabalho está sendo realizado em sete países da América Latina: Bolívia, Brasil, Colômbia, Equador, Guatemala, México e Uruguai. O projeto está sendo apoiado pelo TDR da Organização Mundial da saúde em parceria com o Centro de Pesquisa e Desenvolvimento Internacional do Canadá (IDRC).
